bcl:part.bcl:text: Minimum Siting Standards for All Hazardous Waste Facilities

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person must not establish, construct or operate any hazardous waste facility

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in a 200 year floodplain unless the hazardous waste facility

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is designed, constructed, operated and maintained to prevent washout, or
was in operation on the day this paragraph comes into force, in which case the facility must continue to be protected to the 100 year flood level,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within 100 m of a holocene fault,
in a place which is subject to tsunamis unless the hazardous waste facility is designed, constructed, operated and maintained to prevent washout of any hazardous waste by a tsunami,
within 100 m of any land which is subject to slope failure, or
within the boundaries of any

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: national, Provincial, regional or municipal park,
wildlife management area as designated under section 4 of the Wildlife Act,
critical wildlife area or wildlife sanctuary designated under section 5 of the Wildlife Act,
land acquired and administered under section 3 of the Wildlife Act,
ecological reserve designated under the Ecological Reserve Act,
bird sanctuary designated under the regulations pursuant to the Migratory Birds Convention Act (Canada), or
wildlife area designated under the Canada Wildlife Act (Canada).

bcl:part.bcl:text: Operational Requirements for All Hazardous Waste Facilities

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before beginning the construction or installation of a hazardous waste facility, the owner must obtain approval of any of the following that apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: plans and specifications of new works;
plans for the modification of existing works;
a new operational plan;
a modified operational plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An operational plan under subsection (1) (c) must specify all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: which hazardous wastes will be stored, treated, recycled or disposed of at the facility;
the maximum quantity of each hazardous waste specified under paragraph (a) that the owner estimates will be stored at the facility at any time;
the facility's maximum daily capacity for treating, recycling or disposing of each hazardous waste specified under paragraph (a);
details of the monitoring that will be carried out, including its content and frequency;
details of the reporting that will be provided to a director, including its content and frequency;
details of auditing activities.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The plans and specification referred to in subsection (1) (a) and (b) must include the plans and specifications for the facility's spill containment system.

On or before January 31, 2007, an owner that has not had an operational plan in relation to a facility approved under this section must submit for approval an operational plan that complies with subsections (2) and (2.1).
An owner who obtains the approval required under subsection (1) must carry out the construction, installation and operation of the hazardous waste facility in accordance with the approved plans.

An owner of a facility must not accept, handle, store, treat, destroy or dispose of hazardous waste at the facility or allow it to be accepted, handled, stored, treated, destroyed or disposed of at the facility without taking reasonable measures to identify all hazards associated with the hazardous waste through

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: physical, chemical or biological analyses,
published scientific documentation,
consultation with the waste generator, or
consultation with the manufacturer in the case of manufactured goods which become waste,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: and without limiting the generality of this, the owner must again inquire into and ascertain those hazards wherever that owner has reason to believe that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a process or operation generating a hazardous waste delivered to the facility has changed, or
the description of a hazardous waste received at the facility does not match the description of the hazardous waste on the accompanying waste manifest.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a facility must not accept a hazardous waste that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: does not match the description on the accompanying manifest, or
is not accompanied by a manifest,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: and where any person attempts to deliver such waste to the facility, the owner of the facility must immediately notify a director by telephone to seek

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: authorization to accept the hazardous waste, or
other instructions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not accept, at any hazardous waste facility, hazardous waste which is described as a quantity more than 100 kg or 100 L on the accompanying manifest without first determining the quantity of waste delivered by measuring the weight or volume of the shipment.
Where the quantity of hazardous waste received at a hazardous waste facility is either

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 5% greater than, or
5% less than

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the quantity described in Part A of the manifest, the owner of the facility must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: describe the occurrence of the discrepancy on the manifest,
submit a copy of the manifest, including the description required under paragraph (c), to the director within 3 days of receiving the hazardous waste, and
include the description of the discrepancy in the annual summary required under subsection (5).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If there has been an occurrence of a discrepancy as described in subsection (4), the owner of a hazardous waste facility must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare an annual summary of all occurrences of discrepancies for the previous year,
include in the annual summary an explanation of actions taken to reduce further occurrences of discrepancies, and
submit the annual summary to the director within 60 days of the end of the calendar year in which the discrepancies occurred.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a hazardous waste facility must keep for inspection by an officer an operating record at the facility and must record in a written or retrievable electronic form the following information for each hazardous waste received, stored or shipped:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the description including

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the name and identification number as described in the federal dangerous goods regulations, and
the physical state (i.e. whether it is solid, liquid, gaseous or a combination of one or more of these);

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the quantity in kilograms or litres;
the method and date of storing, repacking, treating or disposing at the facility, cross-referenced to specific manifest document numbers applicable to the hazardous waste;
the location of each hazardous waste within the facility and the quantity at each location.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a hazardous waste facility must keep the records required under subsection (1) for a minimum of 2 years after the waste has been removed from the facility.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person must not operate a hazardous waste facility unless the facility has been designed, constructed and maintained so that elements of the weather such as precipitation, heat, frost, wind and humidity have no detrimental effect on the capability of the facility to manage hazardous waste.
A person must not operate a hazardous waste facility unless access to the facility by unauthorized persons or by animals is prevented by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a 24 hour surveillance system that continuously monitors and controls entry to the facility, and for this purpose television monitors or an approved system, or surveillance guards present at the facility must be used, or
a barrier such as

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a 2.13 m high chain link fence topped with 3 strands of barbed wire to prevent scaling of the fence, or equally effective approved barrier, and
a means of controlled entry, at all times, through gates or other entrances,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: locks or locked covers on all valves, pumps, electrical controls and other operational controls which would be accessible if the prevention measures referred to in paragraph (a) or (b) above were breached, and
a sign, legible from a distance of at least 10 m, reading

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: "DANGER UNAUTHORIZED PERSONNEL KEEP OUT",
"DANGER AUTHORIZED PERSONNEL ONLY", or
"RESTRICTED AREA AUTHORIZED PERSONNEL ONLY",

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: or equivalent wording, posted at each entrance to the facility and at such other locations as a director may fix.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Prevention of fire, explosion and accidental reactions

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a hazardous waste facility must prevent the accidental ignition or reaction of ignitable or reactive waste by protecting such waste from sources of ignition or reaction such as open flames, smoking, grinding and welding, hot surfaces, frictional heat, static, electrical or mechanical sparks, spontaneous ignition from heat producing chemical reactions and radiant heat by means of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: electrical spark grounding where the potential for static buildup exists,
suitable separation distances or a barrier with a minimum fire rating of 2 hours between the waste and ignition sources, and
a warning sign, legible from a distance of 10 m, reading "DANGER IGNITABLE/REACTIVE HAZARDOUS WASTE, NO OPEN FLAMES, SMOKING OR SPARKS".

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of any indoor hazardous waste facility which manages reactive or ignitable hazardous waste must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide and maintain a continuous 24 hour fire alarm system with

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: smoke sensing alarms, and
heat sensing alarms,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: capable of automatically stopping any forced air ventilation systems in the facility and summoning a 24 hour external emergency response through

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a local fire department,
a local response team, or
on site security staff who have immediate communication access to a local response agency,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide and maintain a fire suppression system specified by the Fire Commissioner or a local assistant to the Fire Commissioner as defined in the Fire Services Act, or where not so specified provide and maintain

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a permanent, automatic system which uses foam, inert gas or dry chemical, or
one portable ABC rated fire extinguisher with a minimum 10 kg capacity for every 250 m2 of the facility's space,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide and maintain sufficient aisle space between containers of hazardous waste to allow the unobstructed movement of persons, fire protection equipment, spill control equipment and decontamination equipment to any part of the facility,
design and construct the facility so that the walls, doors and floor are noncombustible with a minimum fire rating of 2 hours, and

ensure that any heat required for the facility is provided only by indirect means such as hot water, steam or electrical resistance and not by any device which uses an open flame within 10 m of where wastes are located, nor by any other device prohibited by the Fire Commissioner or a local assistant to the Fire Commissioner under the Fire Services Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a hazardous waste facility that treats, stores or disposes of ignitable or reactive waste must take precautions to prevent reactions which may do any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: generate extreme heat or pressure, fire or explosions;
produce uncontrolled toxic mists, fumes, dusts or gases in sufficient quantities to threaten human health or the environment;
produce uncontrolled flammable fumes or gases in sufficient quantities to pose a risk of fire or explosion;
damage the structural integrity of the facility.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The owner of a hazardous waste facility must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide and maintain an approved spill containment system to contain on site any release of spilled hazardous waste,
inspect the facility monthly and, where any free liquid hazardous waste is stored at the facility,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: provide and maintain a 24 hour spill alarm system appropriate for the hazardous waste managed at the facility, or

inspect the facility weekly for any irregularities such as malfunctions, deterioration, operator error, leaks or spills which may lead to the escape of hazardous waste from the facility or may pose a threat to human health,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: maintain at the facility a record of inspections conducted as required by paragraph (b) showing

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: any irregularities in the facility,
dates that any such irregularities were discovered,
corrective action taken, and
date of corrective action, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: immediately report any irregularities to a director.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The owner of a hazardous waste facility must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare and maintain in up-to-date readiness a contingency plan, approved by a director, which documents procedures to be followed during emergencies, including

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: shut down procedures,
communication networks to be used, and
notification procedures for

bcl:clause.bcl:text: police departments in the vicinity,
fire departments in the vicinity,
emergency response teams,
ambulance and medical services,
contractors carrying on business in the vicinity,
schools, hospitals and residents,
federal, Provincial and municipal governments,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: evacuation procedures for facility staff,
abatement measures,
inventories of spill response and cleanup equipment available

bcl:clause.bcl:text: at the facility,
from contractors carrying on business in the vicinity,
from agencies operating in the vicinity, and
from regional suppliers,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: appoint one person and at least one alternate to act as an Emergency Response Coordinator with authority to carry out action in accordance with the contingency plan,
provide a copy of the contingency plan to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the Emergency Response Coordinator,
each alternate Emergency Response Coordinator, and
a director, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide clean up equipment, sorbents and other material and protective equipment and clothing, for all emergency response staff at the facility, appropriate for all the hazardous wastes managed at the facility.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a hazardous waste facility must test or inspect

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the fire and explosion protection systems described in section 9 (2),
the spill protection systems described in section 10 (a) and (b), and
the contingency plan described in section 11 (a),

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: at least once a year to ensure that such protective measures, systems, procedures, equipment and clothing are capable of proper operation in an emergency.
The owner of a hazardous waste facility must make a written record of each test carried out as required by subsection (1) and must include in the record

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the measures, systems, procedures, equipment and clothing tested,
a description of the test methods,
the date of the tests on each component,
the results of the tests, and
description and date of any corrective action

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: and the record must be available for inspection by an officer.

Where a facility manages more than 20 tonnes of hazardous waste in a calendar year, the owner of the facility must submit a copy of the record referred to in subsection (2) to a director within 90 days after each test.
The owner of a hazardous waste facility must ensure that every person employed in the operation of the facility receives training which includes instruction on

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the employed person's duties and responsibilities,
use of personnel protective equipment,
fire and explosion response procedures,
spill response procedures,
communications and alarm systems,
use of abatement and cleanup equipment,
shut down operations, and
hazards of all hazardous waste managed at the facility,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: before beginning employment in an operational capacity.
The owner of any facility must provide to each operational staff member an annual review of the training required by subsection (1).
An owner of a facility referred to in subsection (1) must maintain and must produce for inspection whenever required by an officer a record of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all persons employed in the operations of the facility and their duties and responsibilities,
a description of the level of training received by each person so employed, and
the date of the last training session for each person so employed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a hazardous waste facility must not operate the facility unless that owner has prepared a written closure plan and has received approval of the plan.
A closure plan must include

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a schedule of how and when the facility will be closed,
a description of decontamination procedures to be followed,
a description and estimate of the quantity of any hazardous waste residues which will remain at the site after closure, and
an estimate of the total time required to close the facility.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a hazardous waste facility must, whenever changes in the operating plans, facility design or the expected year of closure are intended, submit amendments to the closure plan for approval.
The owner of a hazardous waste facility must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: notify a director within 90 days after receiving or producing the final quantity of hazardous waste at the facility, and

complete the closure of the facility within the period specified in, and in accordance with, the approved closure plan, or, where the closure plan has been amended, in accordance with the approved closure plan and its approved amendments.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a recycle facility must provide an automatic means of stopping

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the process equipment, and
the waste feed system

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: in the event of an accidental release or in circumstances which might lead to an accidental release of a hazardous waste.
The owner of a recycle facility where liquid hazardous waste is being managed must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: use a dripless hose connection, or a containment system that provides equal or better protection than the protection provided by a dripless hose connection, when transferring liquid hazardous waste by means of detachable hoses or pipes, and
ensure that all materials on pipes, pumps, containers and any other equipment which comes in contact with the hazardous waste is compatible with the hazardous waste.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a storage facility where free liquid hazardous waste is stored in containers or tanks must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide space to allow for manual, visual inspection for leaks,
provide and maintain an impervious containment system sufficient to hold the larger of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: 110% of the largest volume of free liquid hazardous waste in any given container or tank, or
25% of the total volume of free liquid hazardous waste in storage,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide controlled forced air ventilation to any indoor facility so that 0.3 m3/min/m2 of a facility is exhausted at all times unless a facility is used solely for passive storage,
provide overflow protection for tanks by means of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: fixed piping to an empty adjacent tank with a capacity equal to or greater than 20% of the protected tank,
a high level alarm set at 90% of the full liquid level of the tank, or
an automatic feed cutoff system set at 95% of the full liquid level of the tank container,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: use a dripless hose connection, or a containment system that provides equal or better protection than the protection provided by a dripless hose connection, when transferring liquid hazardous waste by means of detachable hoses or pipes,
ensure that all materials on pipes, pumps, containers and any other equipment which comes in contact with the hazardous waste is compatible with the hazardous waste, and

ensure that all hazardous waste transfer lines, hoses and pipes are equipped with automatic shutoff or close on failure valves which close off the flow of hazardous waste in the event of a sudden accidental escape unless a method of containment is provided to prevent the release of free liquid hazardous waste.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an owner's primary business is not waste management and the owner's facility provides storage that is on site and passive storage, the owner

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: despite section 4 (1), must prepare and maintain, but unless requested to do so by a director, need not obtain and must not seek approval of, the plans and specifications referred to in section 4 (1) (a) and (b),
despite section 4 (1), unless requested to do so by a director,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: need not prepare or maintain, and
need not obtain, and must not seek approval of,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the operational plans referred to in section 4 (1) (c) and (d),
despite section 11, unless requested to do so by a director, need not obtain and must not seek approval of the contingency plan required by that section, and
despite section 14 (1) and (3), unless requested to do so by a director, need not obtain and must not seek approval of the closure plan, or amendments to the closure plan, required by that section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a storage facility must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any emissions to the atmosphere resulting from the operation of the storage facility are controlled to meet approved emission specifications, and

any discharge of liquid effluent to the environment, to storm sewers or to a municipal or industrial effluent treatment works which results from the operation of the storage facility meets the effluent criteria prescribed in Schedule 1.2.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A director may require an owner of a storage facility to give security for performance of the owner's obligations under the Act and this regulation in the amount and form and subject to the conditions the director may specify.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Additional requirements for storage of PCB wastes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Notwithstanding section 2 (3) to (6) and (8), all storage facilities where

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 1.0 kilogram or more of PCBs,
100 litres or more of PCB liquid, or
100 kilograms or more of PCB solids

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: are stored must comply with sections 3 to 14, 16, 17 and this section.

For the purpose of determining the quantity, volume or weight by which PCBs, PCB liquids or PCB solids exceed the amount specified in subsection (1), the total amounts stored at each location owned or controlled by the same owner or operator must be added together.
The owner of a storage facility used to store PCB wastes must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: drums up to 205 litre capacity used for PCB solids

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 132/92, s. 12 (a).]
are made of 18 gauge steel or heavier,
have a securely attached, close fitting removable steel lid and a gasket of PCB resistant material, and
are painted to prevent rusting,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: drums up to 205 litre capacity used for PCB liquids

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 132/92, s. 12 (b).]
are made of 16 gauge steel for PCB liquids placed in storage or repackaged on or after April 1, 1992 and 18 gauge steel for PCB liquids placed in storage before April 1, 1992,
have a closed top that is fitted with 2 screw plug bungs, and
are painted to prevent rusting,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all containers used for PCB wastes, and all PCB equipment except transformers on skids, must be placed on pallets or an alternate system of storage that allows for visual inspection for leaks and easy removal of the waste,
drums of PCB wastes must not be stacked more than 2 drums high,
containers of PCB wastes other than drums are not stacked unless the containers have been specifically designed for stacking and in such case that they are not stacked more than 2 containers high,
an up-to-date inventory and site map indicating where all PCBs are stored at the facility and a fire safety plan acceptable to the local assistant to the fire commissioner

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: are provided to a director,
are provided to the local assistant to the fire commissioner, and
are kept on site for inspection by an officer,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: capacitors containing 0.5 kilogram or more of chlorobiphenyls are labelled with either Environment Canada's serialized, black and white "CAUTION/ATTENTION PCB" label, measuring 76 mm by 76 mm, or a reasonable alternative, unless the capacitor was stored in a container before this section came into effect,

electrical transformers, electromagnets and other equipment containing chlorobiphenyls in a concentration exceeding 1% by weight are labelled with either Environment Canada's serialized, black and white "ATTENTION PCB" label, measuring 150 mm by 150 mm, or a reasonable alternative,

electrical transformers, electromagnets and other equipment containing chlorobiphenyls in a concentration exceeding 50 parts per million by weight but not greater than 1% by weight are labelled with either Environment Canada's "ATTENTION Contaminated with PCBs" label, or a reasonable alternative,
containers containing chlorobiphenyls in a concentration exceeding 1% by weight are labelled with either Environment Canada's "ATTENTION PCB Waste" label, or a reasonable alternative,

the floor or other surface of the storage site on which undrained PCB equipment or PCB liquids are stored, whether indoors or outdoors, must be constructed of steel, concrete or other durable material,

where undrained PCB equipment or PCB liquids are stored on a floor or other surface of the storage site, whether indoors or outdoors, the floor or surface of the site must be provided with curbing or sides sufficient to contain

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in the case where a single item is being stored, 125% of the volume of the PCB liquid in the item, and
in the case where more than one item is being stored, the greater of twice the volume in the largest item or 25% of the volume of all the PCB liquids stored on the floor or surface,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: where the material of the floor or other surface of the storage site or the curbing or sides referred to in paragraph (k) are capable of absorbing PCBs, they are sealed with a durable PCB resistant coating,

where undrained PCB equipment or PCB liquids are stored on a floor or other surface of the storage site, any existing floor drains, sumps or other openings in the floor are closed and sealed to prevent the escape of liquid,

doors to storage sites, fencing and other security barriers enclosing storage sites are labelled with Environment Canada's non-serialized, black and white "ATTENTION PCB" label, measuring 150 mm by 150 mm, or a reasonable alternative.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 132/92, s. 13.]
The owner of a treatment facility must provide an automatic means of stopping

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the process equipment, and
the waste feed system

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: in the event of an accidental release or in circumstances which might lead to an accidental release of hazardous waste.

Before beginning operation of a treatment facility the owner must conduct an approved demonstration trial to demonstrate the effectiveness of each process intended to treat a hazardous waste that will be received at the facility.
The demonstration trial referred to in subsection (2) must provide

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an adequate test of the treatment process to be used,
a qualitative and quantitative description of the physical, chemical and biological properties of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the hazardous waste to be treated,
any liquid or solid residues remaining after treatment, and
any emissions to the atmosphere resulting from the treatment process,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a description of operating conditions in the treatment process including but not limited to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: temperatures,
pressures, and
residence times, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a description of any conditions which may cause a detrimental effect on human health or the environment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a treatment facility must submit a report with all the information described in subsection (3) to a director before beginning operation of the treatment facility.
The owner of a treatment facility must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any discharge of liquid effluent to the environment, to storm sewers or to a municipal or industrial effluent treatment works which results from the operation of the treatment facility meets the effluent criteria prescribed in Schedule 1.2, and
any emissions to the atmosphere resulting from

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a treatment facility process, or
the ventilation system of a treatment facility,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: meet approved emission specifications.
The owner of a treatment facility must not allow residue to be discharged from the treatment facility unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the residue is managed at a hazardous waste management facility in accordance with this regulation, or

the owner demonstrates to the satisfaction of a director in accordance with test protocols or methods approved by a director under section 53 (1) that the residue no longer poses a hazard to human health or to the environment and that the residue is suitable for

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: disposal to a landfill authorized by a permit, approval under section 15 of the Act, order or waste management plan, or
some other purpose under an approved management option.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Where an owner has demonstrated to a director in accordance with subsection (2) that a residue no longer poses a hazard to human health or to the environment, the director may, notwithstanding section 39, authorize disposal of the residue to a landfill other than a secure landfill.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Requirements for Incinerators and Thermal Facilities

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before beginning construction or installation of an incinerator or thermal treatment facility, the owner must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide a detailed engineering description of the incinerator or thermal treatment facility including the following information:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: manufacturer's name and model number (if available);
type of incinerator or thermal treatment facility;
internal dimension of the incinerator, or thermal treatment facility including the cross sectional area of the process chamber;
description of any auxiliary fuel system including fuel type and feed rate;
capacity of air supply and exhaust systems;
description of the automatic waste feed cutoff system or systems;
any stack gas monitoring and pollution control equipment;
nozzle and burner design if the thermal treatment facility is an incinerator;
construction materials;
location and description of temperature, pressure and flow sensing and control devices,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: predict the maximum ambient ground level concentration of emissions from the facility by means of an approved atmospheric dispersion model, and
submit a report with the information described in paragraphs (a) and (b) to the district director or a director, as applicable.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before beginning operation of an incinerator or thermal treatment facility, the owner must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: conduct a demonstration trial in an approved manner to demonstrate the effectiveness of the facility to treat or destroy hazardous waste, and must conduct the trial for a sufficient time under normal operating conditions to obtain

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a qualitative and quantitative description of the physical, chemical and biological properties of

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the hazardous waste to be incinerated or thermally treated including all principal organic hazardous constituents (POHCs),
any air emissions including all POHCs, products of incomplete combustion (PICs) and parameters listed in Schedule 2,
any liquid effluent discharges including all POHCs, PICs and parameters listed in Schedule 1.2, and
any solid residues including all POHCs, PICs and trace metals listed in Schedule 2,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a determination of the destruction and removal efficiency (DRE), using Equation 1:

oasis:entry.oasis:line: Mass feed rate of one POHC in the waste feed into the incinerator or thermal treatment facility,
Mass emission rate of the same POHC present in the exhaust emissions,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a determination of the combustion efficiency (CE), using Equation 2:

oasis:entry.oasis:line: Concentration of carbon dioxide in exhaust emissions,
Concentration of carbon monoxide in the exhaust emissions,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a determination of operating conditions including but not limited to

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the temperature in the combustion zone or the zone of active thermal treatment,
the residence time of gases in the combustion zone or the zone of active thermal treatment, and
the concentration of excess oxygen in the exhaust emissions

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: whereby the DRE in Equation 1 was determined, and
a determination of specific

bcl:clause.bcl:text: meteorological conditions, and
ambient concentrations of POHCs, PICs and other contaminants

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: as approved, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: submit a report with the information described in paragraph (a) to the district director or a director, as applicable.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The requirement in subsection (2) (a) (iii) does not apply to thermal treatment facilities which generate CO2 from sources other than the combustion process.
The owner of an incinerator or thermal treatment facility must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide an alarm system and an automatic cutoff system to stop the hazardous waste feed to the facility when operating conditions specified in the permit are not met,
test the automatic cutoff system weekly, and
report any malfunction of the automatic cutoff system to the district director or a director, as applicable, within 24 hours after it occurs.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of an incinerator or thermal treatment facility must inspect the facility and all associated equipment such as pumps, valves, conveyors, pipes, etc. daily for any leaks, spills, fugitive emissions and signs of tampering or malfunction.

Any leaks, spills or fugitive emissions from any incinerator or thermal treatment facility must be controlled by keeping the works sealed or by maintaining the internal pressure lower than the atmospheric pressure.
The owner of an incinerator or thermal treatment facility must continuously measure and record for inspection by an officer

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the temperature in the combustion zone or the zone of active thermal treatment,
the waste feed rate,
the gas flow rate at the exit from the combustion zone or the zone of active thermal treatment, and
carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide and oxygen concentrations in the exhaust gas.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of an incinerator or thermal treatment facility must monitor any process emissions for approved parameters at approved intervals.

A report of the emissions monitoring including methods and results must be submitted to the district director or a director, as applicable, within 60 days after completion of the emissions monitoring referred to in subsection (8).
The owner of an incinerator or thermal treatment facility must monitor the ambient air quality and meteorological conditions using approved methods.
A report of the ambient air quality monitoring referred to subsection (10) must be submitted to the district director or a director, as applicable, within 60 days of the end of each calendar quarter.
The owner of an incinerator or thermal treatment facility must ensure that during operation

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the DRE (Equation 1) of the facility is equal to or greater than that specified in Table 1,
the operating conditions are maintained at levels shown by the demonstration trial referred to in section 20 (2) to be necessary to meet the DRE criteria in Table 1,
the CE (Equation 2) of an incinerator is equal to or greater than 99.9%,
the exhaust emissions meet the emission standards as specified in Schedule 2, and

any discharge of liquid effluent to the environment or to any system of waste disposal operated by a municipality or other public authority which results from the operation of an incinerator or thermal treatment facility meets the effluent standards prescribed in Schedule 1.2.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Section 20 (2) and subsections (1) (a), (b), (c) and (d) do not apply to any industrial utility boiler used for destruction of wastes containing low levels of PCBs or PCP, where

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the PCB or PCP content of the waste is less than 500 parts per million,
the minimum rated capacity of the boiler is 15 MW,
the boiler is operated at a minimum of 90% of the design steam generating capacity when the waste is fed into the boiler,
the mass flow rate of the wastes does not exceed 10% of mass flow rate of the fuel into the boiler,

the carbon monoxide concentration in the exhaust gas is not greater than 50 parts per million for a boiler using gaseous or liquid fuel and the carbon monoxide concentration in the exhaust gas for a boiler using solid fuel is not greater than 100 parts per million,
the excess oxygen must be a minimum of 3% when the wastes are being burned, and
the concentrations of carbon monoxide and oxygen in the exhaust gas are monitored in an approved manner when the wastes are being burned.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of an incinerator or thermal treatment facility must not allow solid residue to be discharged from it unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the residue is managed at a hazardous waste management facility in accordance with this regulation, or

the owner demonstrates to the satisfaction of a director in accordance with test protocols or methods approved by a director under section 53 (1) that the residue no longer poses a hazard to human health or to the environment and that the residue is suitable for

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: disposal to a landfill authorized by a permit, approval under section 15 of the Act, order or waste management plan, or
some other purpose under an approved management option.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Where an owner has demonstrated to a director in accordance with subsection (3) that a residue no longer poses a hazard to human health or to the environment, the director may, notwithstanding section 39, authorize disposal of the residue to a landfill other than a secure landfill.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Notwithstanding section 3, where the minister is satisfied that an equivalent level of safety will be maintained, the minister may specify less restrictive siting standards for specific sites on which any mobile facility

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: operates for less than a total of 1 800 hours in any continuous 3 year period, and
treats or destroys less than 1 000 tonnes of hazardous waste during the 3 year period specified in paragraph (a).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before a mobile facility is transported, the owner or operator of the facility must drain all open ended

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: hoses,
pipes, and
containers

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: of any hazardous waste or hazardous reagents and ensure that the hazardous waste or reagents are not released to the environment.

In addition to the annual emergency system testing as required in section 12, the owner of a mobile facility must repeat the test required in section 12 before beginning operation at any new location.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The owner of a mobile facility must comply with the performance requirements pertaining to the appropriate specific type of facilities as prescribed in this Part.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not operate a secure landfill unless a permit has been issued under section 14 of the Act to operate the landfill.

Subsection (1) does not apply in relation to an on-site hazardous waste landfill associated with contaminated site remediation activities undertaken in accordance with the Contaminated Sites Regulation, B.C. Reg. 375/96.

A person must not locate a secure landfill within a wetland area or an area immediately adjacent to a wetland so that natural drainage from the secure landfill would flow directly into a wetland area.

A person must not locate a secure landfill on a site which has a predicted maximum peak seismic acceleration, in percent of gravity, greater than 8% with a probability of 10% exceedence in 50 years as determined from the National Building Code of Canada.
A person must not locate a secure landfill where the landfill (including the underlying dual liners) cannot be constructed

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: entirely above the seasonally high water table, and
with a minimum separation depth of 3 m of unsaturated soil material with a permeability less than 1 x 10-6 cm/s above a seasonally high water table including the zone of capillary rise.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not locate a secure landfill in a recharge area for an unconfined aquifer with one or more high capacity wells (> 100 L/minute) or a significant number of lower capacity wells used for fish hatcheries, domestic, irrigation, industrial, municipal or livestock watering supply.

A person must not locate a secure landfill where it (including the underlying dual liners) would be underlain by less than 5 m of fine grained unconsolidated material with a permeability of less than 1 x 10-6 cm/s over fractured or permeable bedrock formations (e.g. sandstone, limestone, dolomite).
A person must not locate a secure landfill within 300 m of any nonintermittent watercourse or any other permanent waterbody.
A person must not locate a secure landfill within

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a designated community water supply watershed, Category I, as defined in Guidelines for Watershed Management of Crown Lands used as Community Water Supplies,
the Greater Victoria Water District watershed, or
the Greater Vancouver Water District watershed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not locate a secure landfill within an area where

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on average, when calculated on a monthly basis, Pt is greater than Et + Ws, and
on average, when calculated on an annual basis, Pt is greater than Et.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In subsection (8), the formula used must be based on the following:

oasis:entry.oasis:line: precipitation falling on the surface of the closed secure landfill;
maximum possible loss of water from the surface of the closed secure landfill to the atmosphere by evaporation and by transpiration;

available soil water storage in any month in the final cover of the closed secure
landfill (maximum value is total available water storage capacity of the final cover).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not locate a secure landfill unless the person owns and provides an approved secure buffer zone surrounding the active area of the secure landfill.
The owner of a secure landfill must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at appropriate times during construction and installation, inspect

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: synthetic liners and covers to ensure tight seams and joints and the absence of punctures, blisters or tears, and
soil or clay liners for imperfections (e.g. lenses, cracks, channels)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: which would increase permeability,
during operation, inspect weekly and immediately after any storm event or catastrophic events

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: liners, covers and drainage control facilities for evidence of deterioration, malfunction, leaks or improper operation, and
leak detection and leachate collection systems to ensure proper functioning and to determine if leachate is being generated or is accumulating, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: immediately repair or correct any defects or malfunctioning works as determined by any inspections specified in paragraphs (a) and (b) to maintain the integrity of all works.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a secure landfill must carry out an approved monitoring program by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establishing a groundwater monitoring system with a sufficient number of wells, installed at appropriate locations (upgradient and downgradient) and depths to yield from the uppermost aquifer groundwater samples that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: represent the quality of groundwater that would not be affected by any leakage from a secure landfill facility, and
represent the quality of groundwater that would be affected by leachate, if any, from the secure landfill,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ensuring the quality of groundwater monitoring data by

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: casing sampling wells with appropriate materials to ensure the integrity of the boreholes,
preventing contamination

bcl:clause.bcl:text: of any part of the well during construction, and
from the surface during operation, and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: implementing procedures for

bcl:clause.bcl:text: decontamination of sampling equipment,
sample collection,
sample preservation and shipment,
sample custody, and
analytical procedures and quality assurance,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: selecting indicator parameters (e.g. specific conductance, pH, total organic carbon) and chemical constituents for analysis of groundwater that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: provide a reliable indication of the quality of groundwater below the secure landfill from the perspective of human health hazards and environmental quality,
reflect the physical and chemical characteristics of the waste in the secure landfill, and
provide a reliable indication of movement of any contaminant with groundwater flow,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: sampling groundwater sufficiently often to provide data that is representative of varying groundwater flow conditions, but in any case no less frequently than once every 3 months,
measuring the groundwater surface elevation each time the groundwater is sampled,
measuring volumes, sampling and analyzing any leachate collected by the leachate collection system,
ensuring detection of any liquid leaking into the space between the 2 liners, and
reporting monitoring results at intervals specified by a director.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a secure landfill must, as one or more cells are being filled,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: operate under cover of a portable structure that acts as a roof to keep out rain and snow, or
design another system to prevent leachate generation during operation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a secure landfill must, as operations proceed,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: record on a map the exact location and dimensions, including depth of each cell in relation to permanently surveyed benchmarks,
record the contents of each cell and the location of each hazardous waste type within each cell, and
keep records referred to in paragraphs (a) and (b) available for inspection by an officer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a secure landfill must,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within 3 days after detection of leakage into the space between the 2 liners, report the leakage to a director, and
within 3 days after receiving monitoring data indicating non-compliance with respect to groundwater conditions, notify a director.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a secure landfill must empty any leachate or runoff storage facilities so as to maintain sufficient capacity to collect leachate and runoff at all times.
The owner of a secure landfill must not use or operate the secure landfill to dispose of any waste listed in Schedule 3.
The owner of a secure landfill must design, construct, install and maintain a dual liner system

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to prevent any migration of wastes out of the landfill to the adjacent subsurface soil or groundwater during the operating life and after closure,
with both liners constructed of impervious materials that prevent wastes from passing into or through the liner during the life of the facility, and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: if composed of soil or clay, each being not less than 0.5 m thick, and
if synthetic, each being at least 1 mm thick,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: with both liners constructed of materials having appropriate chemical properties, strength and thickness to prevent failure due to any of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: pressure gradients;
contact with the waste or leachate to which the liners may be exposed;
climatic conditions;
stress of installation and operations, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: with the liner system placed on base materials capable of providing support and resistance to pressure gradients above and below the liner system to prevent failure due to compression, uplift or settlement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a secure landfill must design, construct, install and maintain a leachate detection, collection and removal system that includes the following minimum characteristics:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a leak detection system between the 2 liners to detect any leaks or migration of liquid into the space between the liners;
a leachate collection system that is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: installed at a slope greater than 2%, in a porous material drainage layer with a minimum thickness of 0.75 m and permeability greater than 1x10-3 cm/s immediately above the upper liner,
constructed of materials that are

bcl:clause.bcl:text: chemically resistant to waste placed in the landfill and any leachate which might be generated, and
of sufficient strength to prevent failure due to pressure of overlying loads in the secure landfill, and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: designed and constructed to prevent clogging during the life of the facility;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a storage facility suitable to allow removal of leachate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A secure landfill is in a non-compliance situation, with regard to groundwater quality, when analytical data from upgradient and downgradient groundwater monitoring wells for any parameters or chemical constituents are significantly different using approved statistical methods.
The owner of a secure landfill must design, construct and maintain

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a system capable of preventing water from draining onto any cells of the secure landfill, and
a system to collect and control water draining from any cells of the secure landfill

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: during a storm with a magnitude that is exceeded, on average, only once in 25 years.

The owner of a secure landfill must ensure that any discharge of liquid effluent to the environment, to storm sewers or to a municipal or industrial effluent treatment works from the secure landfill meets the effluent criteria prescribed in Schedule 1.2.
If particulate matter subject to wind dispersal is placed in the secure landfill, the owner must cover or otherwise manage the facility to prevent dispersal by wind.
The owner of a secure landfill must, during closure of the landfill or any cell,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make any modifications to works including drainage control, leachate collection, leak detection, monitoring and storage facilities to ensure long term operation with minimum maintenance and security,
install and construct for the secure landfill a final cover with the following minimum characteristics:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: design and construction to function with minimum maintenance;

a foundation layer with a minimum thickness of 0.75 m constructed of soil, or other suitable granular material, compacted to maximum density at optimum moisture content according to acceptable engineering practice, to ensure the overall structural integrity of the final cover;
an intermediate layer of

bcl:clause.bcl:text: not less than 0.50 m of impervious soil or clay, or
an impervious synthetic material not less than 1 mm thick;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a top layer of not less than 0.5 m of soil

bcl:clause.bcl:text: not containing waste, leachate or other material which would contaminate infiltrating water, and
which would provide a suitable long term rooting medium;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: graded and maintained to prevent ponding and having slopes of 3% to 5%;
vegetation which

bcl:clause.bcl:text: is suitable to the area,
is established by approved agronomic practices, and
does not have a rooting depth greater than the depth of the top layer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An owner of a secure landfill must, before closure, prepare, to the satisfaction of a director, a post closure plan for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: maintaining the integrity and effectiveness of the final cover,
maintaining and monitoring the leak detection system, reporting any migration of leachate through the liner,
maintaining and operating the leachate collection and removal system and keeping records of any leachate removed,
maintaining and operating the groundwater monitoring system,
maintaining the drainage control system, and
protecting and maintaining the survey benchmarks.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On completion of closure the owner of the secure landfill site (including its buffer zone) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: comply with the post closure plan approved under subsection (9), and
transfer title of the property to the Crown.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Waste Piles, Surface Impoundments and Land Treatment Facilities

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Siting requirements for waste piles, surface impoundments and land treatment facilities

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not locate a waste pile, surface impoundment or land treatment facility within a wetland area or an area immediately adjacent to a wetland so that natural drainage from the waste pile, surface impoundment or land treatment facility would flow directly into the wetland area.
A person must not locate a waste pile or surface impoundment where it cannot be constructed

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: entirely above the seasonally high water table, and
with a minimum separation depth of 3 m of unsaturated soil material with a permeability less than 1 x 10-6 cm/s above a seasonally high water table including the zone of capillary rise.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not locate a land treatment facility where it cannot be constructed

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: entirely above the seasonally high water table, and
with a minimum separation depth of 1 m of unsaturated soil with a permeability less than 1 x 10-6 cm/s above a seasonally high water table including the zone of capillary rise.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not locate a waste pile, surface impoundment or land treatment facility in a recharge area for an unconfined aquifer with one or more high capacity wells (>100 L/minute) or a significant number of lower capacity wells used for fish hatcheries, domestic, irrigation, industrial, municipal or livestock watering supply.

A person must not locate a waste pile, surface impoundment or land treatment facility where it would be underlain by less than 5 m of fine grained, unconsolidated material with a permeability less than 1 x 10-6 cm/s over fractured or permeable bedrock formations (e.g. sandstone, limestone, dolomite).
A person must not locate a waste pile, surface impoundment or land treatment facility within 150 m of any nonintermittent watercourse or any other permanent waterbody.
A person must not locate a waste pile, surface impoundment or land treatment facility within

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a designated community water supply watershed, Category I, as defined in Guidelines for Watershed Management of Crown Lands used as Community Water Supplies,
the Greater Victoria Water District watershed, or
the Greater Vancouver Water District watershed.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Operational requirements for waste piles, surface impoundments and land treatment facilities

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a waste pile, surface impoundment or land treatment facility must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at appropriate times during construction and installation inspect any

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: synthetic liners to ensure tight seams and joints and the absence of punctures, blisters or tears, and
soil or clay liners for imperfections (e.g. lenses, cracks, channels)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: which would increase permeability,
during operation inspect weekly and immediately after any storm or catastrophic events

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: any liners and drainage control facilities for evidence of deterioration, malfunction, leaks or improper operation, and
leak detection and leachate collection systems to ensure proper functioning and to determine if leachate is being generated or is accumulating, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: immediately undertake to repair or correct any defects or malfunctioning works as determined by any inspections specified in paragraphs (a) and (b) to maintain the integrity of all works.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a waste pile, surface impoundment or land treatment facility must carry out an approved monitoring program by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establishing a groundwater monitoring system with a sufficient number of wells, installed at appropriate locations (upgradient and downgradient) and depths, to yield groundwater samples from the uppermost aquifer that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: represent the quality of groundwater that would not be affected by leakage or leachate, if any, from a surface impoundment, waste pile or land treatment facility, and
represent the quality of groundwater that would be affected by leakage or leachate, if any, from a surface impoundment or by leachate from a waste pile or land treatment facility,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ensuring the quality of groundwater monitoring data by

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: casing sampling wells with appropriate materials to ensure the integrity of the boreholes,
preventing contamination

bcl:clause.bcl:text: of any part of the well during construction, and
from the surface during operation, and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: implementing procedures for

bcl:clause.bcl:text: decontamination of sampling equipment,
sample collection,
sample preservation and shipment,
sample custody, and
analytical procedures and quality assurance,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: selecting indicator parameters (e.g. specific conductance, pH, total organic carbon) and chemical constituents for analysis of groundwater that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: provide a reliable indication of the quality of groundwater below the waste pile, surface impoundment or land treatment facility from the perspective of human health hazards and environmental quality,
reflect the physical and chemical characteristics of the waste being stored or treated, and
provide a reliable indication of movement of any contaminant with groundwater flow,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: sampling groundwater sufficiently often to provide data that is representative of varying groundwater flow conditions, but in any case no less frequently than once every 3 months,
measuring the groundwater surface elevation each time the groundwater is sampled,
measuring volumes, sampling and analyzing leachate or leakage collected, if any, by the leachate collection system,
ensuring detection of any liquid leaking through a liner where a liner is required, and
reporting monitoring results at intervals specified by a director.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a waste pile, surface impoundment or land treatment facility must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within 3 days after detection of leakage through a liner, report the leakage to a director, and
within 3 days after receiving monitoring data indicating non-compliance with respect to groundwater conditions, notify a director.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a waste pile, surface impoundment or land treatment facility must empty any leachate or runoff storage facilities so as to maintain sufficient capacity to collect leachate and runoff at all times.
The owner of a waste pile must not use a waste pile to store

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: waste materials which are or contain free liquids,
ignitable or reactive waste, or
liquids in containers.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a waste pile must design, construct, install, maintain and operate

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an approved containment system to prevent release of any hazardous waste or leachate,
an approved leak detection system to detect any leaks or migration of liquid through any required liners, and
an approved leachate collection system.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A waste pile is in a non-compliance situation, with regard to groundwater quality, when analytical data from upgradient and downgradient groundwater monitoring wells for any parameters or chemical constituents are significantly different using approved statistical methods.

The owner of a waste pile must design, construct and maintain a system capable of preventing water from draining onto the site containing the waste pile during a storm with a magnitude that is exceeded, on average, only once in 25 years.

The owner of a waste pile must ensure that any discharge of liquid effluent to the environment, to storm sewers or to a municipal or industrial effluent treatment works which results from the waste pile meets the effluent criteria prescribed in Schedule 1.2.
If particulate matter, subject to wind dispersal, is placed on the waste pile, the owner must cover or otherwise manage the facility to prevent dispersal by wind.
The owner of a waste pile must during closure remove

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all stored waste, and
any affected underlying soil to an approved depth.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a surface impoundment must not use a surface impoundment to store or treat ignitable or reactive waste.
The owner of a surface impoundment must design, construct, install and maintain

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: sufficient depth in the impoundment to ensure a freeboard of 0.5 m at all times,
an inner, fenced buffer area, 20 m wide, immediately surrounding the impoundment, and
devices to immediately shut off flow of hazardous waste to the impoundment in the event of any malfunction of the works.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a surface impoundment must design, construct, install and maintain an approved liner system

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to prevent any migration of wastes out of the impoundment to the adjacent subsurface soil or groundwater during the operating life and closure period,
constructed of impervious materials that prevent wastes from passing into the liner system during the life of the facility, and that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: if composed of soil or clay materials, is not less than 0.5 m thick, and
if synthetic, is at least 1 mm thick,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: constructed of materials having appropriate chemical properties, strength and thickness to prevent failure due to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: pressure gradients,
contact with the waste or leachate to which it may be exposed,
climatic conditions, and
the stress of installation and daily operations, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: placed on base materials capable of providing support and resistance to pressure gradients above and below the liner system to prevent failure due to compression, uplift or settlement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a surface impoundment must design, construct, install and maintain

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an approved leak detection system to detect any leaks or migration of liquid through any required liners, and
an approved leachate collection system.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A surface impoundment is in a non-compliance situation, with regard to groundwater quality, when analytical data from upgradient and downgradient groundwater monitoring wells for any parameters or chemical constituents are significantly different using approved statistical methods.

The owner of a surface impoundment must design, construct, install and maintain a system capable of preventing surface water from entering the surface impoundment during a storm with a magnitude that is exceeded, on average, only once in 25 years.

The owner of a surface impoundment must ensure that any discharge of liquid effluent to the environment, to storm sewers or to a municipal or industrial effluent treatment works from the surface impoundment meets the effluent criteria prescribed in Schedule 1.2.
If particulate matter, subject to wind dispersal, is placed in a surface impoundment, the owner must cover or otherwise manage the facility to prevent dispersal by wind.
The owner of a surface impoundment must during closure remove

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all stored waste, and
any affected underlying soil to an approved depth.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a land treatment facility must treat only wastes which are approved for treatment in that facility.
The owner of a land treatment facility must design, construct, install and maintain

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an approved system to prevent any release of hazardous waste or leachate,
an approved leak detection system to detect any leaks or migration of liquid through any required liners, and
an approved leachate collection system.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A land treatment facility is in a non-compliance situation, with regard to groundwater quality, when analytical data from upgradient and downgradient groundwater monitoring wells for any parameters or chemical constituents are significantly different using approved statistical methods.
The owner of a land treatment facility must design, construct, install and maintain

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a system capable of preventing surface water from draining onto the site containing the land treatment facility, and
a system to collect and control water draining from a land treatment facility

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: during a storm with a magnitude that is exceeded, on average, only once in 25 years.

The owner of a land treatment facility must ensure that any discharge of liquid effluent to the environment, to storm sewers or to a municipal or industrial effluent treatment works which results from the facility meets the effluent criteria prescribed in Schedule 1.2.

If particulate matter, subject to wind dispersal, is placed on the surface of the land treatment facility, the owner must immediately incorporate the material into the land or otherwise manage the facility to prevent dispersal by wind.
Unless otherwise approved by a director, the owner of a land treatment facility must, during closing, remove

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all residual hazardous waste, and
any affected soil to an approved depth.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not locate a secure building within a wetland area or an area immediately adjacent to a wetland so that natural drainage from the secure building would flow directly into a wetland area.
A person must not locate a secure building where it cannot be constructed

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: entirely above the seasonally high water table, and
with a minimum a separation depth of 3 m of unsaturated soil material with a permeability less than 1 x 10-6 cm/s above a seasonally high water table including the zone of capillary rise.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not locate a secure building where it would be underlain by less than 5 m of fine grained unconsolidated material with a permeability of less than 1 x 10-6 cm/s over fractured or permeable bedrock formations (e.g. sandstone, limestone, dolomite).
A person must not locate a secure building within 100 m of any nonintermittent watercourse or any other permanent waterbody.
A person must not locate a secure building within

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a designated community water supply watershed, Category I, as defined in Guidelines for Watershed Management of Crown Lands used as Community Water Supplies,
the Greater Victoria Water District watershed, or
the Greater Vancouver Water District watershed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a secure building must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at appropriate times during construction and installation inspect

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: synthetic liners to ensure tight seams and joints and the absence of punctures, blisters or tears,
floors, walls, doors, hatches and roofs for defects, and
clay liners for imperfections (e.g. lenses, cracks, channels)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: which would increase permeability,

during operation inspect weekly and immediately after any catastrophic event all floors, walls, doors, hatches, roofs and drainage control facilities, for evidence of deterioration, malfunction, leaks or improper operation, and
immediately repair or correct any defects or malfunctioning works as determined by any inspections specified in paragraphs (a) and (b) so as to maintain the integrity of all works.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a secure building must carry out an approved monitoring program by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establishing a groundwater monitoring system with a sufficient number of wells, installed at appropriate locations (upgradient and downgradient) and depths, to yield from the uppermost aquifer groundwater samples that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: represent the quality of groundwater that would not be affected by leakage, if any, from a secure building, and
represent the quality of groundwater that would be affected by leachate, if any, from a secure building,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ensuring the quality of groundwater monitoring data by

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: casing sampling wells with appropriate materials to ensure the integrity of the boreholes,
preventing contamination

bcl:clause.bcl:text: of any part of the well during construction, and
from the surface during operation, and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: implementing procedures for

bcl:clause.bcl:text: decontamination of sampling equipment,
sample collection,
sample preservation and shipment,
sample custody, and
analytical procedures and quality assurance,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: selecting indicator parameters (e.g. specific conductance, pH, total organic carbon) and chemical constituents for analysis of groundwater that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: provide a reliable indication of the quality of groundwater below the secure landfill from the perspective of human health hazards and environmental quality,
reflect the physical and chemical characteristics of the waste, and
provide a reliable indication of movement of any contaminant with groundwater flow,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: sampling groundwater sufficiently often to provide data that is representative of varying groundwater flow conditions, but in any case no less frequently than once every 3 months,
measuring the groundwater surface elevation each time the groundwater is sampled, and
reporting monitoring results at intervals specified by a director.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a secure building must, as operations proceed, record in tabular and graphic form the exact location and type of hazardous waste in relation to one or more permanently secured datum points and keep this information available for inspection by an officer.
The owner of a secure building must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within 3 days after detecting any defects or malfunctioning works, notify a director, and
within 3 days after receiving monitoring data indicating non-compliance with respect to groundwater conditions, notify a director.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The owner of a secure building must not use it to store any waste which is listed in Schedule 3.
The owner of a secure building must design, construct, install and maintain an approved liner system

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to prevent any migration of leakage from the secure building to any subsurface soil or groundwater during the operating life and closure period,
constructed of impervious materials that prevent wastes from passing into the liner during the life of the facility, and that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: if composed of clay materials, is not less than 0.5 m thick, and
if synthetic, is at least 1 mm thick,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: constructed of materials having appropriate chemical properties, strength and thickness to prevent failure due to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: pressure gradients,
contact with leakage to which it may be exposed, and
stress of installation and operations, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: placed on base materials capable of providing support and resistance to pressure gradients above and below the liner system to prevent failure due to compression, uplift or settlement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A secure building is in a non-compliance situation, with regard to groundwater quality, when analytical data from upgradient and downgradient groundwater monitoring wells for any parameters or chemical constituents are significantly different using approved statistical methods.

The owner of a secure building must design, construct and maintain a system capable of preventing surface water from entering the secure building during a storm with a magnitude that is exceeded, on average, only once in 25 years.

The owner of a secure building must ensure that any discharge of liquid effluent to the environment, to storm sewers or to a municipal or industrial effluent treatment works from the facility meets the effluent criteria prescribed in Schedule 1.2.
The owner of a secure building must, before closure, prepare, to the satisfaction of a director, a post closure plan for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: maintaining the integrity and effectiveness of the entire structure including making repairs as necessary,
maintaining and operating the groundwater monitoring system,
maintaining the drainage control system, and
protecting and maintaining the permanent datum points as references to locate the wastes within the facility.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On completion of closure, the owner of the secure building must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: comply with the post closure plan approved under subsection (6), and
transfer title for the property to the Crown.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A director may require the owner of a secure building to give security for performance of the owner's obligations under the Act and this regulation in the amount and form, and subject to the conditions, the director may specify.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person must not mix or dilute hazardous waste with any solid or liquid, including waste, water or rain water, or otherwise take action by dividing a hazardous waste to evade this regulation or similar regulations in another jurisdiction.
A person must not treat, store or dispose of hazardous waste by means of underground injection.
A person must not operate a hazardous waste facility on a boat, barge or other vessel while it is floating on fresh water, but nothing in this section prohibits the transportation of hazardous waste.

A person must not deposit or discharge or allow or cause hazardous waste to be deposited or discharged into any system of waste disposal operated by a municipality or other public authority unless the deposition or discharge is expressly authorized by a permit, approval, order, regulation or a waste management plan approved by the minister.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), Parts 2, 3 and 4 do not apply to wastes managed in accordance with this Part.
A director may order, in a particular case, that a provision of Part 2, 3 or 4 applies to waste managed in accordance with this Part.

For the purposes of the definition of "waste asbestos" in section 1 (1) of this regulation, if the concentration of asbestos in the waste is not determined by weight at the time of manufacture, it must be determined using one of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Method 600-R-93-116, as amended from time to time, published by the United States Environmental Protection Agency;
NIOSH Method 9002, as amended from time to time, from the NIOSH Manual of Analytical Methods, 4th Edition, published by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, United States.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not deposit waste asbestos in a landfill other than a secure landfill unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a permit or an approval has been issued under the Act to operate the landfill, or the landfill is operated under a waste management plan,
the waste asbestos is confined during handling, storage and transportation by

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: dry airtight containment techniques such as

bcl:clause.bcl:text: packing in 6 mil plastic bags placed within a non-reuseable drum and then sealed, or
packing in a 6 mil plastic bag placed within a second 6 mil plastic bag and then sealed, or

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: wet containment techniques such as saturation with water and containment in non-leaking sealed drums or equivalent, or
approved containment techniques,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the waste asbestos is disposed of at the landfill by being immediately buried with a minimum of 0.5 m of cover material,
approval of the landfill owner is received before disposal takes place, and
the deposit is authorized by a director and carried out in accordance with the director's requirements.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, product fuel means a hydrocarbon for which a Canadian General Standards Board fuel specification exists.
Subject to this section, waste oil may be disposed of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the manufacture of pavement, and
by combustion as a fuel.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person using waste oil as a fuel, or storing waste oil for use as a fuel, without approval, must keep a written record, for inspection by an officer, demonstrating, through analysis using analytical methods specified in section 49, that the waste oil meets the specifications under subsection (5).
Subject to subsection (7), a person must not mix or blend waste oil with any substance other than product fuel for use as fuel or to sell as fuel.
A person may mix or blend waste oil with a substance other than product fuel for use as fuel or to sell as fuel if the person has obtained prior written approval from a director.
A person must not use or sell a mixture or blend of waste oil with product fuel unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the waste oil, prior to the blending or mixing, meets the specifications set out in the table in subsection (5), and

the person keeps a written record, for inspection by an officer, demonstrating, through analysis using analytical methods specified in section 49, that the waste oil meets the required specifications.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), hydrocarbon contaminated soil is authorized for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 179/2016, App. 1, s. 5.]
treatment and storage at any landfill or facility for which an authorization has been issued under the Act, or
use in the manufacture of asphalt,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: if the hydrocarbon contaminated soil meets all of the following specifications:
